Description.val:
The Fiscal Year (FY) 2020 Consolidated Appropriations Act H.R. 1158 appropriated funding in Other Procurement, Navy Line 23X, Ship Maintenance, Repair and Modernization for a pilot program to fund $1B private contracted ship maintenance planned for the Pacific Fleet in FY 2020.  The Pilot Program in FY 2020 funds 16 Pacific Feet private contracted availabilities in OPN.  FY 2021 Presidents Budget Request $1.3B in OPN will improve our ability to execute the potential benefits of conducting this OPN Trial.  The Pilot Program in FY 2021 funds 26 Pacific Feet private contracted availabilities in OPN.

Funding private contracted ship maintenance planned for Pacific Fleet in the OPN pilot allows the Navy to implement commercial best practices for ship maintenance, including extending contract lead times, improved partnerships with industry, and the ability to avoid the "use or lose" aspect of funds in the 4th quarter of the fiscal year.  The Navy can address emergent repair requirements that occur toward the end of the fiscal year without rushing through inefficient contracting processes. If operating under a Continuing Resolution (CR), OPN allows for a better contracting timeline and negotiations, removing an artificially compressed contracting timeline that produces lower-quality 1-year OMN obligations in the fourth quarter. OPN reduces the need to re-shuffle ship repair schedules or to reprioritize the next fiscal year's funding to address shortfalls during the execution of ship repairs. Lastly, since 75% of ship repair contracts conclude in the 2nd and 3rd year when OPN funds are still available for use, with congressional approval, funds included in the pilot could be applied to other repair projects or emergent requirements.

Division A of the Joint Explanatory Statement for H.R. 1158 directs the Navy to submit an execution plan for the funding in Other Procurement, Navy 23x, Ship Maintenance Repair, and Modernization.  The Navy will address the status of the pilot program as directed to include benefits, challenges and failures associated with OPN funding in its quarterly reporting requirement to Congress.  The Navy will report on changes in planning and maintenance schedules, impacts to contracting and execution of funds across the three years. This includes information on the deobligation of funds and the reuse of funds to meet other ship maintenance requirements. During the trial, the Navy would continue to adhere to current above threshold and below threshold reprogramming guidance for OPN funding.     

Ship maintenance is a high priority for the Navy, and the OPN trial provides the Navy with an opportunity to establish and capitalize on best practices and evaluate how OPN can be beneficial for the future of Navy readiness.

Justification.val:
Ship maintenance supports private contracted ship maintenance for Pacific Fleet Command for Fiscal Year 2020 and 2021.

Congressional special interest item increases FY 2020 baseline by $1 Billion for pilot program to fund the private contract ship maintenance planned for the Pacific Fleet Command.  Funding was transferred from OM,N line 1B4B.  As directed, FY 2020 execution plan report was provided to the congressional defense committees prior to the execution of FY 2020 funding.  An updated execution progress report will be provided each quarter thereafter.

FY 2021 requests $1.3 Billion baseline for Pacific Fleet Command to continue private contracted ship maintenance.  Funding for ship maintenance Overhauls (OH) to Restricted/Technical Availabilities (RA/TA) performed at private shipyards.  Ship overhauls restore the ship, including all operating systems that affect safety or combat capability, to established performance standards.

Name.@footnote: FY 2021 Ship Maintenance, Repair and Modernization contract strategy initiatives to properly fund availabilites are based on projected ship availability contract award dates.
